questions.question: What is the role of a test plan in software testing?
options: To provide a schedule for the software release
To document the overall testing strategy and approach
To specify the features to be included in the software
To outline the coding standards for the development team

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a test case?
options: To identify defects in the software
To document the software development process
To design the user interface of the software

questions.question: Which testing level focuses on the overall system integration?
What is the purpose of usability testing?
options: To ensure the software can handle a large number of users
To evaluate the software's user interface and overall user experience
To check the performance of the software under stress
To verify that the software meets specific business requirements

questions.question: What is software testing?
options: The process of finding bugs in software

questions.question: Which testing phase helps ensure that the software works correctly after changes are made?
What is the difference between static testing and dynamic testing?
options: Static testing is performed before coding, and dynamic testing is performed after coding
Static testing involves executing the code, and dynamic testing involves reviewing the code
Static testing is performed by developers, and dynamic testing is performed by testers
There is no difference between static testing and dynamic testing

questions.question: When should testing activities ideally begin in the software development life cycle?
options: Only after the software is deployed

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a primary goal of software testing?
options: Ensuring the software is reliable and stable
Maximizing the development team's coding speed
Ensuring that the software meets requirements

questions.question: What is the significance of automated testing?
options: It can perform tests that are difficult for humans
It is more accurate and repeatable
It is faster than manual testing

questions.question: In which phase are test scripts and test data prepared?
Which phase involves defining the scope, objectives, resources, and schedule for testing?
During which phase are test cases developed based on the software requirements?
Which phase involves comparing the actual results with the expected results?
Which phase ensures that all the test deliverables are finalized and archived?
What is the purpose of the Test Execution phase?
What is the primary goal of the Test Closure phase?
options: To formally close the testing activities

questions.question: Which phase involves summarizing the testing activities and preparing a test summary report?
When is the actual testing of the software carried out?
What is the first phase in the Software Testing Life Cycle (STLC)?
What is the purpose of Acceptance Testing?
options: To verify the correctness of individual units
To ensure that each component functions in isolation
To test the integration between different modules
To validate that the system meets the business requirements

questions.question: Regression testing is primarily associated with which test level?
In which test level is the main focus on ensuring that the software can be deployed and run in the target environment successfully?
Which test level focuses on the interaction between different components or systems?
What is the primary goal of System Testing?
options: To ensure that the system meets the specified requirements
To test the software in a production-like environment
To verify that each unit of the software functions correctly
To validate the integration of different components or systems

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Non-Functional Testing?
options: To validate the integration of different components or systems
To test how well the software performs under specific conditions
To verify the correctness of individual units
To ensure the system meets the specified requirements

questions.question: Which test level typically involves testing the software in a simulated or actual production environment?
Which test level is concerned with finding defects related to security, performance, and usability?
Which test level is often performed by end-users or clients?
What is the purpose of the Unit Testing phase in software testing?
options: To test the entire system as a whole
To test individual components or modules in isolation
To validate that the system meets the specified requirements
To ensure the system performs well under stress

questions.question: Which of the following option is a Test Type?
The difference between Re-testing and Regression Testing is:
options: Re-testing is done after the bugs are fixed; Regression Testing is done earlier.
Re-testing ensures that previously found bugs are fixed; Regression Testing looks for unexpected side-effects.
Re-testing looks for unexpected side-effects; Regression Testing ensures that previously found bugs are fixed.
Re-testing is performed by developers; Regression Testing is performed by independent testers.

questions.question: Non-functional system testing includes:
options: Testing system features using only the software necessary for that function.
Testing the system's quality attributes, including performance and usability.
Testing system features using only the software necessary for that action.
Testing to see where in the system the function is not working correctly.

questions.question: Which of the following is a non-functional testing method? (i) System testing (ii) Performance testing (iii) Availability testing
Functional System Testing:
options: Testing the components containing the system's functions.
Testing whether the system performs functions within a specified time frame.
Testing the system's functions in relation to other systems.
Testing the overall end-to-end functionality of the system.

questions.question: The repetition of testing a previously tested program after it has been changed, in order to detect new errors caused by the changes in the program, is called:
Tính bảo trì (Maintainability) trong ISO/IEC 25010 đề cập đến điều gì?
options: Khả năng của phần mềm để phục hồi sau sự cố
Khả năng của phần mềm để được sửa chữa và cải tiến dễ dàng
Khả năng của phần mềm để thích nghi với yêu cầu thay đổi

questions.question: Tính Safety có liên quan đến điều nào sau đây?
options: Tốc độ xử lý của phần mềm khi gặp tình huống khẩn cấp
Bảo mật hệ thống khỏi các cuộc tấn công
Phát hiện và ngăn chặn lỗi có thể gây nguy hiểm cho người dùng hoặc dữ liệu

questions.question: Tính hiệu suất (Performance) trong ISO/IEC 25010 có thể đo bằng các yếu tố nào?
options: Tốc độ xử lý, thời gian phản hồi, sử dụng tài nguyên
Độ tin cậy, khả năng bảo trì, tính tương thích
Tính năng, khả năng sử dụng, tính bảo mật

questions.question: Tại sao Flexibility là một đặc tính quan trọng của phần mềm?
options: Để giúp phần mềm dễ dàng thích nghi với các yêu cầu hoặc thay đổi mới
Để giúp phần mềm dễ dàng sửa lỗi khi gặp sự cố
Để tăng tốc độ thực thi của phần mềm

questions.question: Đặc tính nào trong ISO/IEC 25010 đề cập đến khả năng phần mềm hoạt động mà không gặp lỗi trong một khoảng thời gian nhất định?
Đặc tính nào trong ISO/IEC 25010 liên quan đến khả năng bảo vệ dữ liệu và thông tin khỏi các mối đe dọa?
Đặc điểm nào sau đây KHÔNG phải là một yếu tố quan trọng của Interaction Capability trong phần mềm?
options: Khả năng tương thích với các phần cứng khác nhau
Khả năng tùy biến giao diện người dùng
Khả năng xử lý lỗi và thông báo cho người dùng

questions.question: Đặc tính nào trong ISO/IEC 25010 đánh giá mức độ mà phần mềm có thể đáp ứng yêu cầu và mong đợi của người dùng?
Đặc tính nào trong ISO/IEC 25010 liên quan đến mức độ dễ dàng mà người dùng có thể sử dụng phần mềm?
Đặc tính nào liên quan đến khả năng phần mềm hoạt động trên nhiều môi trường khác nhau?
What is the significance of defining roles and responsibilities in a test plan?
options: To identify who is responsible for what in the testing process
To assign blame in case of project failure

questions.question: What is the primary focus of risk analysis in a test plan?
options: Identifying potential project risks that may impact testing

questions.question: What is the difference between a test plan and a test case?
options: A test plan outlines the testing approach, while a test case details the steps to execute a specific test.
Test cases and test plans serve the same purpose.
A test case outlines the testing approach, while a test plan details the steps to execute a specific test.

questions.question: What is the importance of defining the entry and exit criteria in a test plan?
options: To identify bugs in the code
To determine when testing should start and end

questions.question: When should a test plan be created in the software development life cycle (SDLC)?
What information is typically included in the test plan regarding the test environment?
Who is responsible for reviewing and approving the test plan?
What is the purpose of a test strategy in relation to a test plan?
options: It identifies bugs in the software
It defines the overall testing approach

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a test plan in software testing?
What does the term 'test coverage' refer to in the context of a test plan?
options: The time taken to execute test cases
The scope of testing in terms of requirements covered
The number of test cases executed

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the Test Management process?
Which aspect of Test Management involves defining the scope, approach, resources, and schedule of intended test activities?
What does Test Estimation primarily focus on?
options: Approximately determining how long a task would take to complete

questions.question: What is the primary objective of Test Management?
options: Ensuring high quality and effectiveness of software testing
Reducing the cost of software development

questions.question: What is the role of a Test Administrator in the test management process?
Which technique is not used for Test Estimation?
What is the primary goal of Test Monitoring and Control in Test Management?
options: To ensure the testing process runs as expected

questions.question: Which kind of risk does not belong to Project Risk?
What is the first step in test estimation using the Work Breakdown Structure technique?
options: Dividing the whole project task into subtasks
Estimating the cost for each task

questions.question: In the Function Point Method of test estimation, what weightage is assigned to a 'Complex' task?
If you are testing an E-wallet application, and you try to transfer funds more than your balance, this is considered as a...
iPhone 8 - iOS 15.1 - 5G Network. Which of the following are the correct environment definitions of the previous elements?
Blocked/Skipped test case means …
options: The test case can't be executed.
The test case is executed and the actual result is different from the expected result.
The test case is executed and the actual result is the same as the expected result.
The test case is not executed.

questions.question: We should never fill the actual result field until executing the test case.
Which of the following is a field in the test case document that should be filled in the test execution phase?

The following steps are the best way to write test steps: 1- Open the internet; 2- Open the laptop; 3- Open the browser; 4- Open the URL; 5- Click on the email field; 6- Enter a valid email; 7- Click on the password field; 8- Enter a valid password; 9- Click on sign in
It is a condition that must be met before executing a test case.
What does a blocked/skipped test case mean?
options: We executed the test case and the actual result is the same as the expected result
We were not able to execute the test case because it depends on another test case that is not passed
We executed the test case and the actual result is different than the expected result

questions.question: A test case is developed based on …
Test cases should be written for which level of testing?
options: Any test level can have written test cases for it

questions.question: What should be included in the "How to reproduce" section of a bug report?
options: The cost of fixing the bug
The name of the person who found the bug

questions.question: In bug reporting, what does the "Status" field indicate?
options: The current state of the bug (e.g., New, Closed, Reopened)
The location where the bug was found
The severity level of the bug
The timeline for the next software update

questions.question: What is a bug report primarily used for?
options: To document how a bug was found and request its fix
To evaluate the performance of testers
To provide a user manual for software

questions.question: Which of the following is a factor in determining bug report priority?
options: The impact of the bug on core functionalities
The color scheme of the software
The geographical location of the bug reporter

questions.question: What does "Status = Duplicate" indicate in a Bug Life Cycle?
options: The bug is being worked on by multiple developers
The bug is critical and needs immediate attention
The bug report is incomplete and requires additional information
The bug has already been reported and logged earlier

questions.question: What does "Status = Re-Open" imply in a Bug Life Cycle?
options: The bug report has been reviewed and needs more information
The bug is considered a low priority and will be fixed later
The bug has been fixed and is pending review
The bug, previously marked as resolved, has reappeared or was not fixed

questions.question: What does a Bug ID represent?
options: The sequence in which bugs are fixed
The person who reported the bug
A unique identification number for the bug

questions.question: How is Priority determined in bug reporting?
options: By the age of the bug
Relating to the defect fixing urgency
According to the number of reports about the bug

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an essential element of a bug report?
options: Function name where the bug was found

questions.question: What does Severity in a bug report indicate?
options: The urgency with which the bug should be fixed
The impact of the defect on the application
The number of users affected by the bug

questions.question: The testing approaches are classified into:
options: Four major categories: test cases, test procedures, test suites, and test characters
Two major categories: likelihood and impact analysis
Three major categories: black-box, white-box, and grey-box
Three major categories: boundary value, decision table, and state transition

questions.question: The testing approach which tests as a user with access to internals is:
''Use cases'' are example of test basis for ...
What is the definition of "test technique"?
options: Documentation of test activities in session-based exploratory testing
A set of test scripts or test procedures to be executed in a specific test run
A sequence of instructions for test execution
A procedure used to define test conditions, design test cases, and specify test data

questions.question: "Detailed design and internal structure" are examples of the test basis for ….
Boundary value analysis is considered as an extension of …
In "Equivalence partitioning", partitions that contain invalid values are called …
In "Equivalence partitioning", the partitions are called …
If we have the following values to represent the equivalence partitions: 0, 3, 6, 9 Which of the following rules is applicable on the value "9"?
options: Each value must belong to one and only one equivalence partition
Any partition may be divided into sub-partitions if required
Each value can belong to one or more equivalence partition

questions.question: The coverage of the Boundary value analysis is measured as …
options: The number of tested equivalence partitions, divided by the total number of identified boundary test values
The number of boundary values tested, divided by the total number of identified equivalence partitions
The number of boundary values tested, divided by the total number of identified boundary test values

questions.question: The equivalence partitioning coverage is measured as …
options: The number of equivalence partitions tested by at least THREE values, divided by the total number of identified equivalence partitions
The number of equivalence partitions tested by at least FOUR values, divided by the total number of identified equivalence partitions
The number of equivalence partitions tested by at least TWO values, divided by the total number of identified equivalence partitions
The number of equivalence partitions tested by at least ONE value, divided by the total number of identified equivalence partitions

questions.question: In "Equivalence partitioning", partitions that contain valid values are called ...
Boundary value analysis can be applied on which of the following test levels?
options: Unit testing, integration testing and system testing
Unit testing, integration testing, system testing and acceptance testing

categories.name: Decision Table and State Transition Testing

questions.question: For conditions with yes or no questions, the Number of table rules equals … (Note: n = number of conditions)
The common minimum coverage standard for decision table testing is …
options: To have at least two test cases per decision rule in the table
To have at least three test cases per decision rule in the table
To have at least four test cases per decision rule in the table
To have at least one test case per decision rule in the table

questions.question: In decision table testing, each column corresponds to a ...
The values of the conditions and actions in decision table testing are usually shown as ............... and for each table these values may have …
options: Boolean or discrete value / same types
Boolean or discrete values / different types

questions.question: When different combinations of conditions result in different outcomes, Which of the following techniques is used?
Coverage in decision table testing is measured as ...
options: The number of decision rules tested by at least one test case, divided by the total number of decision rules
The number of decision rules tested by at least two test cases, divided by the total number of decision rules
The number of decision rules tested by at least three test cases, divided by the total number of decision rules

questions.question: State transition coverage is measured as …
options: The number of states or transitions tested, divided by the total number of states or transitions in the test object
The number of valid events, divided by the total number of states or transitions in the test object
The number of invalid events, divided by the total number of states or transitions in the test object

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct about "State transition diagrams"?
options: A state transition diagram shows only the impossible software states
A state transition diagram shows both the possible and impossible software states
A state transition diagram shows only the possible software states

questions.question: Every independent transition requires a separate test case.
Which of the following is true in the context of State Transition Testing?
options: It is used to test the behavior of a system under varying inputs.
It covers all the possible conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a commonly used technique in use-case testing?

Which of the following statements is true and which is false about "use cases testing"? (1) A use case can be described as interactions, activities, and preconditions; (2) Use cases can include possible variations as error handling; (3) Code is designed to exercise the defined behaviors.
What is a key special attribute of use-case testing?
options: It focuses solely on unit testing.
It is only applicable during the development phase.
It emphasizes the interaction between the system and its users.
It is primarily concerned with system architecture.

questions.question: Use cases specify some behaviors that a subject can perform with ...
What is use-case testing?
options: Testing individual components of a system.
Testing the performance of a system under heavy load.
Testing the functionality of a system based on scenarios that represent real-world usage.
Testing the security features of a software application.

questions.question: What is a common challenge in GUI testing?
What is a recommended solution for managing frequent UI changes in GUI testing?
options: Implementing a robust test automation framework

questions.question: Which of the following is typically considered a common UI bug in GUI testing?
options: Alignment and layout issues in the interface

questions.question: What is a solution to the challenge of ensuring complete test coverage in GUI testing?
options: Limiting the testing to critical functions only

questions.question: In GUI testing, what is a challenge associated with test data and environment setup?
options: Difficulty in creating and managing test data
